lg.l: As the young lady of the earth with an area [that was] wide to the eye
[Her] dress [made of] the wavy waters [of the ocean],
[Her] garland of big rivers, [and her] rain-tresses,
Removing, so that it is gone, [her] cloak [that was] the cover of darkness
The [sun]rise appearing on the summit of big mountains,
Spreading its blossoming rays of shining brightness [upon] the world,
[On] uncovered terraces, the seat of wide vessels [= ships],
The places with palaces with wind-passages [shaped like] deer eyes
On the side of the mouth of the water-body [=estuary],
The seat of the Yavaṉa community that did not know [their] profits to be cut off,
That prevented from leaving those who saw [it] [= made them stop and stare],
The limit of the shining water [= shore/harbour] in which
People who move places with the wealth given by ships - having mingled - remain,
The streets of the city in which those who announce [the price of]
dyes, powders, cool, fragrant sandal, flowers, incense and desired fragrances roam,
The seat of weavers of the fine work of tying [weaving] silk, fur and cotton thread;
Along with the abundance/wealth of cloth, coral, sandal, eaglewood and
Rare ornaments of pearl, sapphire and gold,
[Were] wide streeths in which wealth that knew no end - having been measured -
Along with the divisioned stores that understood the [different] types of categories [of items],
[Were] grain[-selling] streets in which grains were heaped,
And the seat in which washermen/piṭṭu sellers, pancake sellers, ladies selling toddy,
Fishermen [setting] prices for fish, those who announce [the sale of] white salt,
meat sellers, sellers of aromatics and oil-sellers, along with goat-fat sellers, were dense [= congregated],
Those who craft with bell-metal, those who create [out of] copper,
Carpenters who fell trees/wood, smiths with blackened hands,
Those who work with their imagination [= painters], those who lay [= work with] clay,
Smiths who create with gold, those who give good jewellery,
Those who craft [by] tailoring/bards (?), those who tailor (?) leather,
Excelling in several occupations with cloth and with pith,
People that have [many] sections [of expertise] in the work that is done without mistakes,
And seat of the great tunes from the traditions difficult to obtain
Which shoes the opulence of the path [of music]
Having made music without deviation [with] all the eight notes starting with Kural
In the flute and in the lute,
[And] other people of very fine handiwork,
The Maruvūr townside that shines without fault with [such] workers,
The royal, wide street, the street with flags and chariots,
The street with shop counters, the street with the storeyed houses
And the seat of those of the Vedas,
Those of the Veda of longetivity [= Āyurveda] of shining principles,
Along with ploughmen from excellent homes, astrologers of time,
And the seat of many kinds, in which the types of sections were evident,
The wide, large street with those who cleave [= shape] bangles for adorning,
Along with the superior principles of those who set/string brilliant sapphires,
Those who calculate of [auspicious] hours, painters that obtain goodness [=talent],
Women who sell flowers, servant girls to be commanded,
And the seat that is clear in categories, with joking panegyrists,
Those with instruments in occupations [that require] training, those with many kinds of devices,
And the large, spread-out seat that surrounded the outside [of the center of town],
Those who spur on fast horses, mahouts for elephant bulls,
Those who mount tall chariots [and] brave men with cruel eyes having stayed [there],
And the Paṭṭiṉam townside of an excellence that is worthy of song,
In which [the number of] great people with an excellence that has greatness increased;
Like the place on a battlefield with two great kings,
At a treegrove with platforms to whose legs shop[stalls] were tied,
At the day-market that was permanent, without trembling [= without instability]
[With] the sound of those who give [= sellers] and the sound of those who take [= buy],
Because the Cittirai month and the [full] moon of Cittirai month had come together,
[The people of the town], saying, ‘May there be an end to what is experienced [=suffered]
For the king with a victorious spear’,
At the altar that had an entrace, with a watchful protective deity
That had its origins in the command of the king of Gods (Indra),
Pouring forth [onto the altar] boiled [food], a sesame preparation,
A cooked item with fat, flowers, incense and toddy,
Those who danced the Tuṇaṅku dance [and] those who danced the Kuravai dance
Dancing, the spirit having risen [in them],
[The people] praising, saying ‘In the great land of the king with a vast land,
Death, hunger, sickness and enmity being eliminated’,
From ancient houses that speak with skill
The valorous warriors from the Maruvūr side [of town]
And the people that have weapons from the Paṭṭiṉam side [of town],
‘May there be an end to what is experienced [=suffered]
For the king with a victorious spear’, saying,
‘May [the offering] be the [only] limit for the strength of those who perform the sacrificial donations’;
Those with slings that shoot stone, those that are spread out,
With spotted shields to which flesh is attached,
Rubbing together, so that their bodies touch,
Those who took the battlefield, roaring,
Having placed, so that goodness is obtained,
The black heads [= rotting heads] with glowing glances whose ends had become red,
- Frightening [onlookers] - From the full thicket of battle
[The king] having feed the pure offering
With the Muracu drum with a fur eye
Of a loudness of the voice of thunder,
That [in itself] eats the offering of life [i.e. played when people are killed on the battlefield]
The brilliant, great Vaḷavaṉ, because there was fighting everywhere,
[He] not having obtained fighters [= opponents] [yet] upon the large [battle]ground,
Moving [= departing] with an [auspicious] day, the sword, the parasol and the Muracu drum with a fur[-covered] eye,
Saying [to the Gods] ‘May my shoulders that have strength obtain enemies [to fight]
Upon this earth’, on that day,
So that [only] a desire for anrelenting/unweary zeal [for battle] remains behind [with the king],
Saying, ’That which hindered enemies [= invaders] is this mountain of yield/plenty’,
At the nape of the summit where immortals remains,
And the marquee of victory that was given as tribute
By the king of the good land of Vacciram, with a fence of big waters,
To those who returned [in accordance] with [his own] tenets,
Having engraved the [tiger with] curved stripes [on the site of conquest],
And the pavillion of debate given by the king of light truth
Of the land of the Makataṉ, to whom enemies showed their backs [i.e., fled in battle],
And the door with festoons of the rising, high tradition
Given by the king of Avanti as a friend [lit., as he who rejoices],
Even though their were made out of gold and out of sapphires,
They were of those customs [of craftmanship] that were not seen
These were indeed of the custome [of craftmanship] that was given, having been decreed
by Mayaṉ, [in exchange] for the services [of aforementioned kings’] ancestors
Of an excellence from which misery departed.
Besides [this] pavilion of a custom difficult to obtain,
That are praised by superior people,
And the entrance door with treasures [stored in them]
[The doors] that had undergone the writings of the eye
Upon which new people [i.e., strangers] had engraved their names,
Being one that had renounced the securty of a black lock
And the security of those who possesed [weapons, or aforementioned ‘poti’]
And a white, open space [in which]
Having lifted [the thieves’] heads so that they whirl,
Not giving in [i.e., not surrendering] to giving [them the treasures inside],
Which makes those who think of it tremble
And the structure with the tank
In which hunchbacks, dwarves, the mute and the deaf,
And those with decaying bodies [i.e., probably leprosy],
Having bathed as they who submerge [themselves in the water],
Having obtained a good colour of a sight that is faultless,
And the structure that stood [like] a long stone from which light flowed,
In which the misery of those who were possessed with maddening enmity, having consumed deceit,
Those who possessed trembling misery, having consumed poison,
Those into whom the [venom-]full fang of the snake with a hot [i.e., poisonous] mouth was sunken
[And] those who experienced the punishment that was quick [to arrive] of the demon with eyes [large like] an anklet,
Left, as they prayed, having come hastily [i.e., whirling-ly],
And the square of the Pūtam, in which the Pūtam [a malignant spirit] eats, having thrashed
Those without a good nature, behaving [falsely by] hiding behind penance,
Adulterous women who behave [falsely by] hiding behind vanity,
Ministers who decline [= who become corrupt], those who desire another’s wife,
Those who bear false witness [and] those who speak [behind one’s] back,
Raising its harsh voice [that reached up to] even four leagues,
Saying, ‘They will fall to my hand, with the cord held [in my] hand!’,
And the structure of the doll, in which the doll cries
Having shed tears for punishments/faults, not speaking with the tongue
Even if the sceptre of the king bends,
And even if [only] one [wayward] aspect is captured,
The treatise [of the law] that is spoken in the court
Which talks of [i.e., dictates] duty, having been twisted,
Having offered a rare offering to the five-typed structure
That is praised by great people who realised the way of truth,
Having raised the drum that had fragrance
From the enclosure of the Vacciram [weapon],
Upon the nape of the neck of an elephant with a[n ornamental] belt,
In the enclosure that glowed of the king with a pure white elephant-bull [Indra],
Having declared the end-state of the festival that was held [at this] time,
In the enclosure of a state of giving, [with] the [people’s] principle of staying [there]
Having raised, so that it touches the sky, an auspicious, long banner,
Everywhere, at the entrance of a tall palace,
With a platform/pavillion/terrace of fresh gold [i.e., the best quality gold]
Having set emerald gems along with diamonds [into them],
A crocodile[-shaped] wreath upon which auspicious [signs] were impressed,
With a pattern of shining pearls [that spill from] the split-open mouth [of a fish] [that was] a spout,
An earthen pot that glittered with a pot full [with] green gold from which fault was cut away,
Around which (?) festoons were made permanent [i.e., built to last],
doll-shaped lamps, banners of green gold,
Chowries of pure fur and beautiful powders,
Crowding [together] on the street of the principle of [giving you what you] desire,
Five big herds, retinues that were [too] big to count,
Sons of kings, sons of fishermen,
Those with horses with a seizing [i.e., wide] gait, those of the discipline of [training] bull-elephants,
[And] those of chariots with climbing horses, enjoying, having gathered together,
In the wide place where the king was eminent,
Saying, ‘May the king who is worthy of being talked about obtain victory’,
Of the great ghat where pollen is abundant of cool, fragrant Kāviri
Which guards the living in this large world,
So that the earth is confused [by wonder], so that the skies are amazed,
Bathing with excellent water the leader of the celestials (Intiraṉ),
[In] the temple of the great one with a body that was not born (Śiva),
The decorated, glittering temple of Murukaṉ with six faces, (Skanda)
The temple of the white one with a body [like] pure bangles [made of conch], (Balarāma)
The temple of the tall one with a blue body (Viṣṇu),
And the temple of the king with a garlanded, white parasol,
The order of the fire from the tradition of the four secrets/Vedas
That do not deviate from the truthfulness of the great, ancient first one,
The four types of gods, the eighteen Kaṇas
The festival of the different kinds of Gods
In the appearance of the [regional] divisions that knew the manner of division [i.e., that knew how to stand out/be distinct],
The resting-place for virtuous ones, and the hermitage [of those who] protect Araṉ,
The blessed place of the enclosure on the outside [of the city],
On one side, the actions that are narrated by able ones excelling,
On one side, mercy increasing as the foot-shackles of kings
That do not join the [= our] king with a bannered chariot are released,
poet-scholars with melodious lutes along with singing bards,
Of a superiority that is difficult to count, excelling,
Alleys and streets [in which] the eye of the drum was sleepless,
Over there, in the nature in which the intoxicating festival was superior,
Along with Mātavi with beautiful, curved earrings,
Who did not obtain gossip having separated from her beloved husband,
[Kōvalaṉ], flourishing with a garland of dense flowers,
waterlily [grown in a] pot [and] lotus that is red all around,
[Kōvalaṉ and Mātavi], having reached [a state of] passionate, intoxicated joy,
Settling into [love-]sports in the fragrant grove with hoards of flowers,
The new fragrance of the forests abundant with flowers having entered
The daily marketplace in the place of daily joy,
Incense and sandal paste excelling without fading,
[Kōvalaṉ and Mātavi] engaging in good words with
In the streets in which the Mārutam wind from the Malaya region roams
Along with the bards with mouths [that sing] the kuraḷ note,
Along with the rabble-rousers of the city,
[Just] like Kōvalaṉ with the habit of roaming about,
Along with the bees with mouths [that sing] the iḷi note,
Along with the sweet, young summer season,
Saying, Having borne black [rain-]clouds, Having eliminated the little hare,
Having drawn in the middle of two black carps [the eyes] the kumiḻ flower [for the nose],
Is it indeed so, the wandering of the moon over here [on earth],
Having feared the enmity of the snake in the sky over there?
Having drunk the auspicious water in excellent droplets
Of the ambrosia of the long[-lasting] land of the moon with a watery mouth,
Is it indeed so, the coming of the sky-creeper [lightning]
That was raised so that he with the raised banner of the fish obtained a body?
Is it indeed so, the roaming of the deceptive lotus
Searching in disguise for its companion,
As though having flowered [as] the black, long waterlily [as her eyes]
And the kumiḻ flower [as her nose],
Apart from the fire-coloured silk-cotton flower [as her mouth],
Thinking, ‘This must be the prosperous abode -
The one which the lady Tiru entered,
In order to show her great wealth to the king of the big earth’?
Is there a pretext for Kūṟṟam with a gaping mouth that consumed many lives,
Having feared the refusal of the straight [= just] sceptre of the king,
Not turning [away from] his difficult tasks [of trapping victims],
To wander [about] in femininity [= in the disguise of a lady],
Having bent the face into a smile in a shame-possessing countenance,
Prattling like the strings that speak [the language of] melody
Saying, ‘Won’t this great limit of big ground [= the earth]
Give any antidote at all, if [even] the red ends [of eyes]
Are not abated by [the hosting of] guests —
[The red ends of eyes that were] waterlily buds with sapphire petals
That went, having given their backs [= rejected],
[Those eyes] upon the beautiful, lustrous faces of women who stay at home,
With the chastity of the North Star,
Who united with propriety, having united [= made love]
In staying together with [their] husbands with great shoulders
Upon the entire body [of the new woman], the drawn, lined patterns
Blocking [i.e., rejecting], having stood opposite the ladies of hostile battle [i.e., a temptress],
Of the singular, great army of the man without a form?’
In the middle of the day with good work [= the festivities],
In which [the aforementioned ladies] trembled helplessly,
As the inside driped fragrant pollen [= the eyes dripped with tears], perishing,
Like a lotus that shivers, as it sheds nectar,
The black eyes of Kaṇṇaki, and the red eyes of Mātavi,
Hiding the fullness [of tears] in the inside [of their eye],
In the way that they think [about the past],
[Their eyes] twitched, be it left or right,
On the day of the festival of the king of the celestials.
